metadata.title: Machine Learning detects Fake News. | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Developing a Data Science Model to Predict Fake News
metadata.description: Using Python, Random Forest, GridSearchCV, and NLP to classify if your article is fake. Data science and machine learning tutorial on model-building.

all_paragraphs: Deciphering if a news article is valid or not can be difficult. As a new author on Towards Data Science, Analytics Vidhya, and DataSeries, I have gained some intuition into developing an eye for what is fake or real. Instead of purely relying on a hunch, I wanted to test my theory using data science and machine learning. I have compiled Python code that constructs a Random Forest model to predict whether or not an article is fake. As a Data Scientist, I have always been curious about creativity and automation — I believe my article and work on this model combines both facets of science and art to predict news’ validity. Below, I outline the code that I used for this model, as well as commentary on further work, and a summary for non-technical users who are interested in the characteristics of a true article.

The dataset used in this model was created from my dummy data. I am using several features or characteristics about common articles and trying to predict if they are fake or not. In my case, false is determined by a predetermined label, as well as true. For the sake of this tutorial, this data is randomly generated from my own text. The great thing about this data and model is that it can be scaled and redefined, say you compile several articles from more sources, your labels can be real-world articles from Facebook, Twitter, or even the New York Times. Now that we know about my target variable, fake (or true), let us look into which features I used to build the model:
Below are the first five rows of the dataframe:

Because both text and numeric features are used in this model, natural language processing (NLP) is beneficial for prediction. I used the common term-frequency inverse document frequency vectorizer to transform the count of text into a weighed matrix of term importance. I then compiled both the TextTransformer and TfidfVectorizer for the text features like title and subtitle. Next, I performed a similar method, but for numeric features using the NumberTransformerr class. Lastly, I combined all of the features, text and numeric together. The code [3] used below is for feature engineering, NLP, and ultimately to prepare/preprocess the data so that it can be inputted into the model correctly.

The next part of the data science process, and perhaps the most fun, is to create a model that predicts your target variable. In this case, the model is a Random Forest classifier. I created a general classifier, then united all the features and classifier together in a pipeline. I isolated the features from the variable, y, and stored those accordingly for later reference. The next step was performing a train-test split on the data, while establishing a train and test size 70:30, and then incorporating a random state for reproducibility. To see how the model performs on new data, develop this split, and ultimately test on data that is completely unseen (which would be the real-world application of a model).

The next step was to create a parameter grid for GridSearchCV to search through. This grid is used to test several listed parameters and to see which is the best one. For my model, I looked at the n_estimators. I created an object that stores the estimator which is the pipeline already created, with the param_grid, a cv (cross-validation) fold of 2, n_jobs of 1 (for faster computing), verbose of 1 (to see textual output), and return_train_score for model diagnostics. Not only did I look at the mean_train_score, but I also wanted to see how useful the model was at looking at new data with the mean_test_score as well. I found out which parameters were best as well with grid_search.best_params that helped to distinguish that 30 number of estimators were best.

In non-data science vocabulary, feature importance refers to which parts of a dataset are great for predicting the response variable, or in this case, an article’s features are important and with how much weight are they important. Because this model is new and the data is small, I looked at plotting the highest features (most were text), since the features used are all important.

With any data science model and dataset, it is important to note that not one feature is the main reason for a prediction, or in this case, if an article is fake. It is the combination of them that works to create an article that is false or true. While my analysis and model are great at predicting, it is mostly great at classifying on my own data.
